DOC.HEAD: Acid Leak in Switzerland
DOC.TEXT: A storage tank leaked at a chemical plant Thursday, sending up a stinging, toxic cloud of acid that drifted over the Swiss-French border, authorities said. Residents were warned to close windows and stay indoors for more than an hour as the cigar-shaped cloud, about 1,000 yards long, drifted toward France. The chlorosulfonic acid, which is used in the manufacture of dyes, leaked from a tank at Ciba-Geigy, Switzerland's largest chemical company. Four workers and eight residents were treated for irritated eyes and coughing; two of these were hospitalized. Chlorosulfonic acid can cause lung injuries if inhaled for some time. The accident occurred while the acid was being pumped from a railway tanker into a storage tank, the company said. Special fire brigades from Ciba Geigy and nearby companies would remain on the site until the over-filled storage tank was safely emptied. The accident set off the biggest alarm in the Basel region since a 1986 toxic spill in the Rhine River caused one of Europe's worst environmental disasters.
